symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits, dark lesions with yellow halos.
treatment: Spray copper-based bactericides every 7–10 days. Remove and destroy infected plant parts.
prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds. Avoid overhead irrigation to keep foliage dry. Practice crop rotation with non-host plants.

symptoms: Brown to black leaf spots with characteristic 'target spot' or concentric rings, leading to defoliation.
treatment: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb every 7–10 days, especially during humid weather.
prevention: Use certified disease-free seed tubers, rotate crops with non-solanaceous plants, and remove plant debris after harvest.

symptoms: Dark spots with concentric rings ('target spots') on lower leaves, which turn yellow and fall off.
treatment: Spray fungicides like Mancozeb or chlorothalonil every 7–10 days upon first sign of disease.
prevention: Avoid overhead watering, rotate crops annually with non-related plants, and maintain good garden sanitation.

symptoms: Large, water-soaked, greasy-looking lesions that turn dark brown on leaves and stems, with white fungal growth on leaf undersides.
treatment: Spray fungicides like Mancozeb or metalaxyl every 7 days during cool, wet weather.
prevention: Use resistant varieties, avoid overhead irrigation, space plants for good air circulation, and remove affected plant debris.

symptoms: Yellowish-green spots on upper leaf surfaces, with corresponding grayish, velvety mold growth on the undersides.
treatment: Apply fungicides like copper oxychloride or sulfur. Improve air circulation by pruning and spacing plants.
prevention: Avoid high humidity, provide good ventilation (especially in greenhouses), and avoid overhead irrigation.

symptoms: Numerous small, circular spots with dark brown margins and gray or tan centers on leaves. Small black dots (fruiting bodies) may appear in the center.
treatment: Spray fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based products regularly. Remove and destroy infected lower leaves.
prevention: Practice crop rotation, avoid wetting the foliage when watering, and plant resistant varieties if available.

symptoms: Yellow stippling or tiny dots on leaves, fine webbing on the undersides of leaves and between stems.
treatment: Use miticides like abamectin, spiromesifen, or spray horticultural oils like neem oil. Increase humidity to disrupt their life cycle.
prevention: Avoid drought stress on plants, regularly inspect leaf undersides, and introduce natural predators like predatory mites.

symptoms: Dark, necrotic spots with distinct concentric rings, similar to Early Blight but often smaller, appearing on leaves, stems, and fruits.
treatment: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb every 7–10 days.
prevention: Ensure good air circulation, avoid leaf wetness by using drip irrigation, and rotate crops.

symptoms: Severe yellowing and upward curling of young leaves, stunted plant growth, and significant reduction in fruit production.
treatment: There is no chemical cure for the virus itself. Control the whitefly vector using systemic insecticides like imidacloprid.
prevention: Use resistant plant varieties, remove and destroy infected plants immediately, and control whitefly populations with yellow sticky traps or insecticides.

treatment: No cure available. Immediately remove and destroy infected plants to prevent spread.
prevention: Use certified virus-free seeds, sanitize tools and hands regularly, and avoid using tobacco products around tomato plants as they can carry the virus.
